I loved this game. It was short and sweet, and even though it had no dialogue or human emotions I ended up feeling really attached to my digital badger mother and pups. Totally recommend if you're into story-oriented games. Waiting for Shelter 2 to come out.

Shelter is by no means a long game, neither is it very deep on a gameplay or mechanical level. That said, Might and Delight have undoubtedly worked to their strengths to make a game that I won't forget. In Shelter you control a mother badger protecting her five cubs. While it's also a very linear game it never presents you with a goal. This is perfect, as the player I was always focusing on the task at hand, remaining in the present I tackled what faced me, rather than think about what was ahead. I found this to be very suited to a game where you control an animal, considering animals mostly think in the present. Unlike us humans.

Interestingly enough, for one of the first times in a game I hardly thought selfishly about my own character's safety. I was always worried about my little baby badgers, not thinking about myself, or my own safety, I didn't even consider if I could get hurt or hungry myself.

It's lucky you don't have to worry too much about your own safety, since caring for five badger cubs doesn't come easy. I won't ruin the ways in which you can lose them, but lets just say you probably won't get through Shelter without losing the majority of them. Each time I lost a badger cub was actually rather depressing. I was the one who felt like a monster, not the thing that took it away. However with each cub I lost, feeding the remaining ones became much easier, a guilty reminder I had failed them.

Feeding the cubs is a simple matter of uprooting a carrot, headbutting a tree to make apples fall or pouncing on a small rodent or fox. The cubs can't acquire the food themselves, so once you obtain the food you have the choice of which badger to give it to. A cub's hunger is determined by the tone of it's fur, when it's markings are more of a grey tone you know it needs to be fed. That said, this isn't very easy to tell nor does the game tell you this, so often you have to rely on your memory for which one to feed next. Obviously this works nicely as it adds to the pressure.

As a few final notes, Shelter doesn't look like a horror game, but in many ways it is. I haven't been so afraid and stressed in a video game for such a long time. I was obsessively counting how many cubs I had left, even jumping out of my skin at any sudden noises. This was definitely helped by the fact I played the game in one sitting without getting up. I was extremely absorbed, often forgetting I was was playing a game. It left me with a great new experience but not one I want to repeat any time soon. The most heartbreaking moment that comes to mind; I was hiding in a bush with my last two cubs. As we were moving around in the undergrowth I could swear I saw a third cub, for a second my heart leaped. Alas, on closer inspection there wasn't a third, I knew true and well he/she wasn't alive anymore.

So all in all, I highly recommend anyone anyone to give Shelter a try. Like I said earlier it isn't long, only clocking 88 minutes to finish it myself. The gameplay isn't very deep either, but it left me with an experience I will never forget. That experience alone certainly makes it worth full price to me. And I haven't even talked about how brilliant the game looks and sounds. However, if you don't want to take that risk be sure to pick it up in a sale. Remember to play it in one sitting, no interruptions, all the way to the end of the credits.

Originally posted on my blog: http://d-facegames.blogspot.co.uk/2014/04/my-thunks-shelter.html

I personally find it hard, to get a game, perhaps an exploration, that I thoroughly enjoy. Games such as Dear Esther. Shelter has a special glow to it that makes the game extraordinary. Then again, the game is awful. Now don’t get me wrong. I admire the game, and for the small price it is very much worth it. But… the games flaws are big, yet unfixable. The games flaws almost have nothing to do with the game, its the person. But, before I get to the things wrong with it, why don’t I state whats good about it. For one, its a badger simulator, now who wouldn’t want to play that? The game has beautiful graphics and the art style is different and is amazing. The lighting however should be changeable. The entire game is done with a pastel, almost opaque color. It is almost uncomfortable to look at and can get very annoying at times. Especially during the night. When almost everything is a grayish blue, its hard to find food, keep track of the 5 badgers (I had only one at the time) and see where you are going. Besides the colorm I found its hard to keep the badgers with you. Crouching, or pressing control will bring the badgers to you but only as you hold the key. If the young cubs spot food, they will automatically remove themselves from their mother and hop around it. This can get very annoying. Also, if something frightens the badgers they will run to safety. This happened to me, and my 1 badger and soon I was down to 0 badgers. I looked everywhere, but it was at night and the badger was gone. One issue I have is how quickly the badgers will begin to starve. I lost 3 of my badgers to starvation during the bird of prey section in the beginning of the game. There is no food along the path and I got lost with the several safety patches. I mean really, it is so hard to keep the badgers with and keep them alive. Im amazed how long I was able to keep them with me. I have been a bit too negative though. I don’t want it to sound like a bad game because, it is not at all a bad game. Not even close. The gameplay is smooth and the controls are simple and easily mastered. With only 6 keys and the mouse there are no confusing shortcuts and pointless keys to worry about. The sound effects in this game help far more than you’d think, along with shadows. Hearing the call and seeing the shadow of the large bird of prey will ensure that you get to safety soon and give you fair warnings as to when you may be about to be attacked. At night, many sounds may scare your cubs, or you, but the small call you do will help handfuls to find missing cubs. I like the boundaries by the water to ensure that no baby badgers are sent down to their doom. This game is absolutely extraordinary and is sure to have you playing hours straight.

Despite its duration, the adventure you take through Shelter's beautiful world is worth taking. I literally shouted out loud when a hawk took one of my cubs and the ending provides a opportunity for the player to think about life from perspectives other than their own.

This game isn't long; it took me 68 minutes to complete. I was really intrigued by the concept, and at first I just thought it was a bit funny. After a while I grew attached to my little baby badgers, and quickly learnt to keep them alive at all costs. When one died, it made me sad. The game is kinda sad all the way through. The ending was the most depressing thing ever. It might be coz I smoked a blunt half way through but I was really sad when it finished. It felt like my soul had been torn from my mortal frame. 10/10.
I love the concept and atmosphere of this game! Baby badgers are so cute... I only wished the game was longer and had more challenges.

This game is flat out amazing!  The music and origami-looking graphics are amazing.  As you try to survive against all sorts of terrors you become so conntected with the badgers.  When I lost my first (and last) badger I felt so sad.  I would recomeened this game to anyone.  The short length is understanable and doesn't bring the game down at all.

Shelter's a nice short game, don't know if I would of paid the full price on it, but it's been on sale quite a few times to where its more responsibility priced for the game itself. Overall your a badger, what else could one want in life?
If you ever wanted to be a mother badger and enjoy watching your cubs die, this is a game for you. Short but sweet.

Let's get the essentials out of the way: a. Shelter is short. b. Shelter is not an open-world survival sim, or even, really, aiming to be a realistic survival sim at all, beyond the fact that you're keeping five badger kits alive for two hours. Or . . . trying to. Gameplay's pretty simple. Feed your babies. Don't let them get eaten, drowned, or set on fire. And that's it. But simple as it is, it's a game you can screw up, or a game that can screw you up. Helps that the babies and the landscape are both lovingly designed, and so you're all I must protect you babies, but this landscape wants to devour you and I can't just put you in a safe basket and drag you through the four or five levels, here. When the game's working best, it's anxiety-inducing to lose track of your kids. I had this one point where I thought I lost all of them, and I ended up running my badger around in circles in a broad simulation of aaaaaah. It's good for that. Keep in mind.
don't know where this game will lead the player! The visual effect is so beautiful! The life of badgers feels good,but not enough!

Don't you want to save little badgers, you bad person?!\nReally creative game. Awesome artwork and an even better soundtrack!\nMaybe it's a little bit short (~3h) for the price of €8,99 but the experience is awesome!
Amazing game, short but poignant; the answer to years of game journalists pointing to motherhood as an untapped conceptual well in gaming.
Is it normal to cry and never play again when you lose the babbuls?

Shelter is a short game but extremely memorable!

Shelter really draws you into the life of the mother badger as she journeys with her cubs. Before playing this game, I thought that losing a cub would be a blow to my pride (didn't play well enough to keep them all) more than anything else. However, I lost two of my five cubs in one stage and I found myself mourning them for the rest of the game.

No other game has made me panic on a level like this. A mistake does not impact the player directly (mother badger) but costs the life of one of the cubs. It is devestating. Additionally, the slow-pace of the game makes the urgency of certain scenes extremely effective.

I have never played a game like this and recommend a play through.

The music and visuals are gorgeous and really draw you into the game. They match really well and create a wonderful atmosphere.

The length of the game really lets it down. At 1.5hrs for my play-through, I was very upset to see the journey end. It would have been great to see the story continue for a little longer than it did. That said, I still think it is worth purchasing for the experience.

In summary:
Worth a play-through for the experience

Positive
- Compelling gameplay
- Beautiful music and visuals

Negative
- Very short (1-2hrs)

reviewText: This is definitely a title that falls outside the gaming norms. While fundamentally simple and straight forward, Shelter sets the stage for you to feel what it is like to be in the middle of the food chain. It is an experience that you have to be willing to assemble in your own mind. You make your own story in the minimialist framework that is provided. So if you're someone who likes to ponder what ifs, such as life from other prespectives, then this is a great game to try out. If that's not your thing, then you're just wasting your money.

This game is quite gorgeous, in a simplistic way. Same goes for the gameplay; very simple, but intriguing. It stimulates a larger range of emotion than one might think, from admiration and wonder, to even nervousness or fear. The soundtrack is pretty immersive as well, and fits the mood of the environment as well as the player. The game is kind of slow-paced, but I didn't expect a fast-paced game when I bought it. If you want a completely different and unique experience, give Shelter a try.

Shelter is by no means a long game, neither is it very deep on a gameplay or mechanical level. That said, Might and Delight have undoubtedly worked to their strengths to make a game that I won't forget. In Shelter you control a mother badger protecting her five cubs. While it's also a very linear game it never presents you with a goal. This is perfect, as the player I was always focusing on the task at hand, remaining in the present I tackled what faced me, rather than think about what was ahead. I found this to be very suited to a game where you control an animal, considering animals mostly think in the present. Unlike us humans.

Interestingly enough, for one of the first times in a game I hardly thought selfishly about my own character's safety. I was always worried about my little baby badgers, not thinking about myself, or my own safety, I didn't even consider if I could get hurt or hungry myself.

It's lucky you don't have to worry too much about your own safety, since caring for five badger cubs doesn't come easy. I won't ruin the ways in which you can lose them, but lets just say you probably won't get through Shelter without losing the majority of them. Each time I lost a badger cub was actually rather depressing. I was the one who felt like a monster, not the thing that took it away. However with each cub I lost, feeding the remaining ones became much easier, a guilty reminder I had failed them.

Feeding the cubs is a simple matter of uprooting a carrot, headbutting a tree to make apples fall or pouncing on a small rodent or fox. The cubs can't acquire the food themselves, so once you obtain the food you have the choice of which badger to give it to. A cub's hunger is determined by the tone of it's fur, when it's markings are more of a grey tone you know it needs to be fed. That said, this isn't very easy to tell nor does the game tell you this, so often you have to rely on your memory for which one to feed next. Obviously this works nicely as it adds to the pressure.

As a few final notes, Shelter doesn't look like a horror game, but in many ways it is. I haven't been so afraid and stressed in a video game for such a long time. I was obsessively counting how many cubs I had left, even jumping out of my skin at any sudden noises. This was definitely helped by the fact I played the game in one sitting without getting up. I was extremely absorbed, often forgetting I was was playing a game. It left me with a great new experience but not one I want to repeat any time soon. The most heartbreaking moment that comes to mind; I was hiding in a bush with my last two cubs. As we were moving around in the undergrowth I could swear I saw a third cub, for a second my heart leaped. Alas, on closer inspection there wasn't a third, I knew true and well he/she wasn't alive anymore.

So all in all, I highly recommend anyone anyone to give Shelter a try. Like I said earlier it isn't long, only clocking 88 minutes to finish it myself. The gameplay isn't very deep either, but it left me with an experience I will never forget. That experience alone certainly makes it worth full price to me. And I haven't even talked about how brilliant the game looks and sounds. However, if you don't want to take that risk be sure to pick it up in a sale. Remember to play it in one sitting, no interruptions, all the way to the end of the credits.

Originally posted on my blog: http://d-facegames.blogspot.co.uk/2014/04/my-thunks-shelter.html

Shelter is a beautiful and charming game where you are a mother badger tasked with the responsibilities of taking care of your five pups. Some gamers may find this simulation too linear, but the structure allows for it to be divided into chapters which shake up the mainly slow-paced action. The game is beautiful, made up of pastel textures stitched onto the world which change with the acts and colour palettes. It is a heartwarming journey in which you are able to witness the growth of your pups as they grow in size and speed, but it leaves you with a gnawing sense of failure in the almost inevitable death of your pups due to hunger, predation or just nature itself. But please fellow gamers, I implore you all to get this game. It's not too long - only around 2 hours long, and the ending is an extraordinary ode to motherhood that leaves you with a sense of legacy, grief and hope.

Beautiful and engaging, if a bit short. Comparing it to AAA titles is pointless; Shelter is art in the form of a video game, with a very specific concept and goal that, in my opinion, was beautifully executed. Highly recommend picking it up for $2.50, but I would probably not pay full price given that I completed it in an hour and a half.

This game is a like an interactive nature documentary about badgers. The graphics and music is surreal, which gives it a relaxed and subtle feel. Much in the game is subtle and requires intituition (for example the cubs will fade in colour as their fatigue and hunger raises). There are no power-ups nor special abilities. This is a game about a mother badger, that can die and so can her cubs. I enjoy the realism blended with the surreal graphics.

The game is very linear and the environment leads you down the story. I think this game would make a great pilot to an open world nature game. I hope this game goes on to inspire larger and more immersive nature games.

All and all, great game, albeit short. (Buy on sale)
This game was short, but I felt so much parential instinct for my little babies. Only two survived -- I hope they enjoy their apple forest.

I'm usually the type of guy who is slower at completing a game than other people, but I managed to finish this in 1.5 hours.  No complain in regards to the length of this game; in fact, I find that the length of it is just adequate.  If the game is longer, I probably couldn't have finished it in one sitting, and that would destroy the whole experience of it.

By the way, I think if anyone going to play this game, it's best to finish it in one sitting.  It's like you watch a whole movie, except it is better; because you are more involved in it, you are controlling the badger in the game, and you are more attached to it.

So, this game is all about playing mother badger sheltering her cubs from harm.  And there really isn't any story or plot in this game, but it makes you think about the deeper things that you normally won't think about.  After I finished this game, I thought about it for a long time, even when I'm lying on bed.  I thought about the existence of these badger, the existence of myself, or just life in general.

Nowadays, I've been playing and looking for games that's 'different' from others.  And I truly hope there are more games like this one.  I highly recommend this if you want a unique and wonderful gaming experience.

I have bought the Shelter when it had a promotion price discount. I had heared about this game before and I wanted to check it out because the review that I've heared were very positive.
The whole completion of the game took me 1 h 30 m. However, I have to admit that the game is very well done. It is unlike anything else. The controls and gameplay are rather straight forward, nevertheless it still makes you strongly care about your small fluffy heroes.
I have to praise the atmosphere created by the developers. Despite the graphics are not particularly intricate, they grasped my attention because of the sophisticated impressionistic style which added up to the whole game universe.
The game itself makes you appreciate things that we usually wouldn't notice. The plot twist was a cherry on the cake, even in spite of being slightly predictable.
To sum up, I recommend this game to every gamer, as it is something unlike the usual games. Appreciate it rather as a piece of art, then a challenge (which you can find there as well :) ).

Shelter is an intriguing concept the developer neglected to actually construct a game around.

The mechanics are incredibly simple and never build in any way, such that any given minute of the game is virtually indistinguishable from any other minute. Go forward. Grab food. Occassionally go fast or go slow to avoid some hazard. There is no particular goal, no score kept, and no story, so there is no sense of progression or urgency.

Your single goal is to keep the badger cubs alive, but they have no personality, no narrative surrounding them, and there is no penalty if they die, so there is no emotional connection to them: You won't really care if they die or not.

I don't know how long the game is, because I didn't finish it, but however long it is, it's too long, because the game's charm wears off after about 15 minutes, and once the charm is gone, there is no reason to keep playing.

Shelter is a unique little game. Where you are a mother Badger with 5 cubs to take care of.
You need to survive 5 areas with your cubs. You lead them, feed them, save them from other animals while you cross lands and waters to a safe place.
It's kinda a survival game, without HUD or surviving bars on screen.

Pros:- Refreshing, new take on survival games concept.
- Atmospheric and nice music
- Edgy & Emotional. Sometimes it makes you happy, laugh, worried, guilty or depressed.

Cons:- Too Easy to get lost because of the level design
- Suicidal cubs AI
- Short game (Not really bad for me, but probably severe for some others)

Conclusions:Yes. I recommend this game if you want a fresh breath from loudy games.

So If you don't have a problem buying a short game for $10, go ahead. Otherwise wait for a sale.

reviewText:
A short (~1 hour) game showing the cycle of life and possibly  what a bad ♥♥♥♥ing mother you can be.

It's  sweet  and it makes me wanna kill myself. Totally recommend it.

It also has a really calm/sad soundtrack so I urge you to buy it as well.

I like the graphics of the game, especially the sky is marvelous at times. However, I didn't find the gameplay too interesting. For me it was too grindy, I felt like all I was doing was running around collecting food. There was no progression other than the environment I was collecting the food in. I played the game for about one hour before I couldn't be bothered anymore, I realize that's not long enough to give it a solid review, but I felt like I'd experienced just as much of the game after my first 20 minutes as I had after a short hour.\n\nIf you are the kind of player that can really immerse yourself in the game and feel a strong connection to your cubs, and like to grind, this might be a game for you. However, this wasn't my cup of tea and from my experience of it I can't recommend it with a clear conscience.

Shelter is a game where you are a momma badger in an adventure with your five lil badgers through the seasons of the year in the woods. You'll probably end up with just one surviving them all, though.
Even though the aesthetic is beautiful, the gameplay itself is pretty tame. I missed some kind of inventory or maybe a health bar for the little badgers. Also, the camera was a bit messy sometimes.

If I were a badger, I'd rather have no children.

a gr8 game accept for one thing, Theres no way to save. Besides that great. THe soundtrack is good and so are thee graphics. I fell off a cliff. My babies followed.


11/10 would kill babies again

reviewText:
It's said that the greatest despair that a parent can face in life is the loss of a child.
Shelter is a small story that you play which mimics parental love and the sorrow of loss by making you take care of five young badgers (You're the mommy badger) who need to be fed and protected as you go across the dangerous wilderness through day or night.
I've noticed you should always try to keep them more or less fed at the same level or else the one that's least fed doesn't grow as much and becomes slower, therefore your possibility of loss of that young one is higher.
I've loved playing this little story/simulation for it actually makes you want to protect the little ones as if it is your responsability - and when you lose one, it actually hurts.

It also has a very distinct and great look to the game, with various textures to give that abstract depth of the wild life, the soundtrack choices are great for each moment...
All I can say is that I loved it. Now it's time for you to find out if you're able to feel the pain of a mother.

reviewText:
Shelter is an experiment in what the medium of gaming can provide as an experience. It goes outside the mould of standard gaming conventions and instead chooses to tell a tale about a Badger mother who must look after her cubs while traversing vast distance in search of a new home. While the game is only about an hour long, it is one of those games that any game connoisseur should not miss out on.

If you are only into games for the pointless grinding and getting as many hours out of a single game and exposure as you can until the value of that experience essentially approaches zero, this game is not for you. If you enjoy seeing the breadth and scope of the medium, and enjoy playing a large variety of games, this one is worth a look.

Overall this game is a welcome venture into a way of play that should be expanded upon in the future to fully reach it's potential.

reviewText: The visuals are pretty, the music is nice and fits the pace of the game really well, the idea/theme of the game is interesting and fun, but why on earth is the gamma set so high? It's a real eyesore, especially during the night time section--its a dark night but the darkness is almost blindingly bright. You can kind of tell from the screenshots that it looks like someone dropped a whitewash or bleach over the entire game, and it is even more noticeable when playing.\n\nThe things I were doing seemed to have little impact on the game as well. I actually replayed it after completion to see if feeding my badgers actually did anything. Spoiler alert: it does, but there is so much food in the game that if one of them starves you've either got your eyes closed or are blinded from the ridiculously high gamma. The description asks Food is to be found
date: but is there enough for everyone?" and the answer is yes. Definitely.\n\nPros: Good art style (if you can see it through the gamma) Music Bonus game

reviewText:
This game has been on my wishlist for ages and I only wished I had picked it up earlier.
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=s1-u2wez_ns
In Shelter you get to experience the wild as a mother badger sheltering her cubs from harm. On their journey they get stalked by a bird of prey, encounter perils of the night, river rapids crossings, big forest fires and the looming threat of death by starvation.

Food is to be found, but is there enough for everyone? You will learn that the cubs need food not just to survive, but to enable them overcome the varying challenges they will face as they make their way through the world. The question in the end is who will survive to live another day?  - Recommended!

reviewText:
While I did enjoy the story and the graphics were very very interesting and amazing (in their own artistic way)... there wasn't much to the game.  It felt a bit misleading to what the game would be about.... which really is walking through enviroments trying to keep your babies alive... only to be met with your own fate at the end... yeah.. spoiler... but you might as well know it now before buying this game.

I did enjoy it... and would recommend people to play it, but I wouldn't recommend it for anything more than Free to Play (or when it's on sale... as it is as of this review).

There's just about 0 replayability to the game, and while that's not /terrible/ .... it certainly isn't worth very much to buy a game that takes, for me, just over an hour to play, only to be met with nothing different on another iteration of the game.

I commend the developers, ten-fold, for the game, as it really does have a high sense of artistic creativity stuffed in such a quick game, but must ask that in future updates, possibly have more of a RND aspect to the events therein.  At least some new aspects or areas... or expand the game a littlle more than it's at.

Otherwise... there's 0 gripes about this fabulous work of artistry!

When danger comes around, you put them as a priorty and you must keep them fed. You find youself constantly checking if all you cubs are still with you (I even gave them all names :3 ). The eviroment changes around 5 times from Autumn rain to Frosty winter to predator filled night-time!

Different but really nicely designed graphics and the soundtracks are amazing.  Overall a game that is fun,  engaging, sometimes exhilarating and sad all at the same time. 9/10

reviewText:
Right so i have been utterly dying to play Shelter 2 for ages as it looks awesome, but i am far too tight to pay the full price so i have been waiting for it to go on sale. It hasn't yet, but this one did today and while i am not as interested in Badgers as a Lynx, i coughed up the money and bought it.

And i actually regret it....
It wasn't a bad game by any means, it was just not a lot of game for my money, even at half price.

There is very little in the way of a tutorial and the beginning of the game was rather confusing, as half the time it doesn't tell you what to do. But i started with five lovely cubs- after eventually figuring out that i had to feed one of them at the start to carry on in the game. And to start with it's a nice game. Feeding five cubs is actually rather demanding and i searched for food all the time. Though catching the Foxes is really hard. I only caught one and i never caught a frog at all. xD And keeping your cubs safe from the evil birds and wolves was quite fun and challenging, on my first play through.

I lost four and only managed to get one to the end. :( And the ending, wow. Not what i was expecting at all and personally i don't like it. But for £3 something this game doesn't have a lot in it and for full price it's certainly not worth it.
1) You pretty much just walk in a predetermined direction, while picking up food and feeding your cubs, while trying (and failing) to avoid getting them killed.
2) And there are only 5 levels, which took me just over an hour to get through and that's with replaying the last one.
3) It does have some replay value, as i will try and get all five cubs to the end, but once i have done that, it will probably just sit in my library gathering dust.

Which is unfortunate really, as this game could be much more. There are not nearly enough animal simulation games out there.

So in the end, it's not a bad game and i was rather gutted when i lost each one of my cubs, it's just not much of a game and i would therefore sorta recommend it, but only at half price or more preferably. (I will put not recommended though, as i just think it's too expensive for what it is.)

reviewText:
I have never played anything quite like Shelter.  Visually stunning, and emotionally resonant, this is one of the most memorable games I've played in quite a while.  It's the sort of game you have to experience for yourself to truly appreciate.

Throughout the gorgeous landcapes, death is everywhere.  Your cubs don't have the experience you do; all they know is that you, their mother, will protect them.  But you are just a speck in the vast outdoors, and nature doesn't care about your pitiful pleas for mercy.

This game is what indie games are all about (for me). Totally breaks the mold of what a traditional game should be about, look like, or play like. It's certainly not for everyone, but everyone should still play it. Such a beautiful, artistic gem. I enjoyed this game immensely.

reviewText:
a really short game, though a heartwarming one.
I could tell that I was really starting to care about the baby badgers just like what a mother would, especially when one of them was taken by the darkness in the evening stage. The sad thing is, just like in reality, there is no save and load option and it would never come back. :(
Was really enjoying feeding them and watching them grow into the size of mother badger, satisfaction filled up easily just by successfully getting them a fox for the dinner, As for the last stage before the eagle's strike, I kinda sensed that something's gonna happen because of the vast plateau in front of me, nowhere else to hide and sooner or later the babies are going to starve to death if I dont proceed.
But what I really like about the game is that at the end the game shows the eagle took the mother badger back to feed its children, a what seems like sheer evil has resolved into a equally motherlike character, just like our protagonist badger.

reviewText: Pointless walking simulator. So basically this game is just wandering around doing absolutely nothing except feeding your cubs, dodging a bird, and walking around. It looked pretty good in the trailers, but it's actually just plain boring. I bought this thinking it was a game where you can explore wherever you want, but you're actually on a set path. This game is barely worth the $2 I payed for it on sale, and you'd have to be crazy to pay $10 for it. One of the reasons I purchased Shelter was because of how nice the graphics looked, but once I started playing, I realized they weren't as good as they seemed. You can barely read the title screen because everything blends in with the background. Everything is really lightly colored. Nothing looks very realistic, and everything is made out of shapes.\nThis game is not worth buying. Maybe it would be if it looked truly realistic, you could jump, fall off ledges, etc.\nI honestly don't know why this recieves so many good reviews. People say the game brings them to tears. People say the game is cute. People say the game is fun. They're wrong. If you want a good game for $10, go buy Undertale, it's so much better.

reviewText:
AUDIO: Atmospheric                                               AESTHETIC: Pretty
MEMORABILITY: Endearing                                   WORTH: Discount

PROS: The crumpley paper-mache look throughout the whole game is very beautiful.  The colors in this game are superb and transition well. It is a very emotive experience.

CONS: Often, it's poorly conveyed as to what you're to do or where you're to go. Gaming has come up with very small touches like artistic highlighting or proper camera use to push the player in the right direction while avoiding damages to the aesthetic, but Shelter utilizes few of them. The game also happens upon severe crashes for both me and my friend. Reinstallation did not help for either of us.

OVERALL: I want to be able to finish this game, but have been unable to because of the constant crashing. My friend whom I had bought this for is on a completely different system and is dealing with similar crashes. These seem to be problems only some are dealing with. I'm NOT warning you against purchasing this game since not many people are dealing with this, only informing you of my experience.

SCORE: 5/10

reviewText:
An interesting experiment is what I would call this game, but overall it fails to provide a reason to pay $10 (at the time of this review without discount).

The game places you in the feet of a mother badger who must direct her cubs through different perils until they reach shelter. These perils consist of starvation, hawks, fire, water rapids, and unessen creatures of the night.

The gameplay consists of guiding your badgers and trying to keep them fed by finding various food around the world, or by hunting down live animals like frogs or rats. Most of the time though the game is a giant escort mission where you make sure your badgerlings aren't carried off by a hawk or rapid by stealthily running from cover to cover and hoping your children follow.

The game is also very short consisting of 6 or so levels which only round out about an hour of gameplay. There is a little replayability but it is possible to lose children along the way and continue the game, so reaching the end with all 5 children intact could extend your time with the game if you so wanted.

The graphics look a bit like papercraft which gives the game a very unique style and can produce some beautiful scenery. Sometimes though there is a sort of white wash that is very noticibly placed over everything which really hurts the vibrant aspect of the world.

With all of this said I can not recommend this game

reviewText:
I bought this game because the premise was simple and from the video, the style was very neat - in a sense that it was interesting. It is, by far, 'neat'. While the game is fun, I had to change the controls to something more.. easily accessable. It took a little bit to figure out what to do, since it just throws you into the game.

First, I gotta say I love the models for the badgers and foxes. They're widdle and adorable. The noises and music are really nice, too. The second level gives you the 'creepy mood' without being over powering.

The textures are very... messy. Tiling textures can be a pain, but looking at textures sloppily added onto the objects is also a pain - on the eyes. The textures are nice, but since nothing seems to tile, it just looks like a big, unfinished mess to me. The grass patches are obvious squares that go in alternating directions. It wouldn't take too long to easily make the textures they have tile, becuase they are already quite simple; full ambient, no shading. It is unique in it's own little style, though. You quicky get over it and enjoy the game. I think at first I just found it rather jarring.  I think my biggest pet peeve is the sky at night. Would it really be so hard to add glowing dots rather than what they have?? It looked like the cieling to a children's bedroom.

The camera seems to get weird during some places, and it doesn't matter if it's close up or far away. Sometimes it just... does a weird 'thing'. Turns itself around? Suddenly too sensitive? It's hard to explain, but it's super prominent in the second level, which was hard to explore. The levels aren't linear - which is usually a good thing - but I find it easy to get lost, only being able to know where I've been from the holes of wild growing.. turnips? I thought they were potted plants, at first. Hehe.

Anyway. The game is simple; maybe too simple. It's still fun, and I feel really bad for losing 2 cubs on the second level! If the textures tiled nicely, and didn't look like they were done in 10 minutes, this would be an awesome little game. It's easy to get attatched to your cubs once you figure out what you have to do, which can take a while to notice. From a distance, the environments are kinda pretty~

10$ is actually quite a lot considering, so I'm glad I got it for $2.50.

reviewText: Shelter is a great game with unique graphics, gameplay, and sounds. You take the roll of a mother badger fighting to keep your  young alive and to overcome many obstacles. It may be short, but it is a very entertaining game to play and a great experiance to go with it. The best time to buy it would to be on a sale, since it is a tad overpriced. The game soundtrack is absolutly awesome, as it keeps is mostly mellow mellow, unless there is danger. Besides the wildernes challenges, there is also the hard challenge of keeping your pups alive, which can be hard. Overall it is a great game, the only problem I had was when it lagged horribly during the night. I would reccemend this to my friends, especially on a sale though when it is cheaper.

reviewText:
Hmm, who would have thought something like this could work out so well? A game about a mother badger feeding and protecting her cubs from the dangerous wildnerness that constantly keeps you on your toes.

The game consists of 5 levels, each one with a unique theme, the first being a sort of calmer, introductory level to teach players the mechanics of the game (feeding, hunting and hiding), quickly moving on to the scary Night time, an hostile environment that easily scares the cubs, having them running into the predator's den. Then, you'll deal with a rainny day, traversing through overflowing rivers that might just drown you if you're not careful, after that leading to a Fiery forest, trying to keep the flames at bay.

All this while trying not to be caught by an eagle, the antagonist" of this game (or is it?)
date: concluding everything in the last level
recommended: a constant hide and seek between the two species.\nThis was an unexpected game
hoursPlayed: with a unique graphic style
voteText: and very beautifully done! The game brings a feeling of persistent consequence everytime a cub is lost
helpfulPercent: since there is no going back after one has been killed. As a result
votesHelpful: you're constantly on your toes
votesTotal: and
votesFunny: despite its limited length
commentsCount: it's totally worth the time and money. There's the possibility of multiple playthroughs
column16: trying to save as many cubs as possible.\n\nOverall a very positive experience
column17: which I'll go through at least once again to see how different it is after a good grasp of the  ways of surviving. I'd advise anyone looking for something different to play it."

voteText: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Shelter is an amazing game.

You play as a mother badger, tasked with feeding and protecting your five cubs, as you travel the world filled with rich atmosphere. A lot of your time is spent running around, locating or reaching food, and avoiding dangers not for yourself but for your vulnerable pups. The only real defense you have against the natural predators that stalk your pups is stealth, size, and determination. You WILL lose one of your babies, and you will be forced to move on immediately for the sake of the rest of your pups.

This game has a lot of atmosphere and beauty to it. The type of game that you play for the experience. Sometimes it can be slow, or tedious, and at times it can also feel like a linear path which can take away from the world that is built around you. But it's far too easy to become immersed, to name your individual pups only to realize that your favorte one had gotten swept away by a bird of prey or by the powerful river. The repetition of survival feels present with each life.

For anyone that enjoys an immersive, beautiful-looking and beautiful-sounding game, Shelter is for you. If you happen to also enjoy a dash of nature and is fascinated by the cruel challenges of wildlife, then this game delivers.
However, if you need a game to have stimulating and exciting gameplay, and do not care for the idea of animal-sim games, then take extra consideration before purchasing this game. I will say that, for it's humble price, it has plenty to offer right off the bat.

Interesting premise to the game but if you are going to do a tutorial of the controls may I suggest doing it BEFORE you need it?

reviewText:
NOTE: I actually do recommend this game, if you're a fan of SHORT, indie, minimalist games. I value my experience at about $1, and I wouldn't recommend paying more than that. I finished the game in just under an hour.

Shelter was short so I'll try to be too. You're a parent badger and you need to get your 5 cubs to safety. You will forage for food and avoid predators and other dangers along the way. How many babies can you get to the finish? Shelter has a low-poly minimalist style, and I think this is a detriment to the game. What is food doing? Does it help? How much? How urgent is it versus rushing past everything? The game didn't communicate this. The game occurs over 4 medium-ish sized levels.

With so little to talk about, because there's so little to the game, I was expecting more emotion in the experience, and it didn't really do it for me. Moral of the story: Nature is harsh, so pump out those babies, everyone!

reviewText:
I don't think I can play this again.
:(


...To elaborate:

Shelter is a game about bonding, nurturing, self-sacrifice and loss.

It is unusual that the key objective is to protect and guide something vulnerable and helpless, when the more common objective in games as a rule is to destroy, conquer or demonstrate superiority.  Plenty of games may contain an element of protecting/guilding, such as ‘escorting’ an NPC but this is generally a side note, a means to an end and (more often than not) a hindrance.

Shelter encourages you to bond with your offspring right from the get go in the tutorial, where you have to carry food to your cub who is dying of starvation and literally fading away. The risks and difficulty of keeping the cubs alive are continually, and heartbreakingly, ramped up. As well as trying to keep individuals from starving (when cubs will happily try to out compete rival siblings) there are an array of external threats – predators, the natural environment, getting left too far behind, etc. There is an urgency. Hiding while a giant avian predator lets out a piercing cry and the shadow of its wingspan falls over you is genuinely filled with tension.

This isn't a game to be won so much as an experience to be felt.  And Shelter communicates that experience very effectively...perhaps too effectively, which is why I'm not prepared to put myself through the ringer again (despite thoroughly recommending the game for both intention and execution).

reviewText:
It is worth the two dollars because of the effort put on this, and the good intentions behind it.
I wanted to like this game.
- Sound and graphics are nice.
- Feels are effectively felt.
- Controls feel wrong.
- Progress can't be saved.
- If you want to play full screen, you cannot switch back to window mode while playing, you have to stop the game and start all over again.
... and you will want to switch to window mode, because you have to read the forum for instructions.
- The first ten minutes were very frustrating, apparently you have to feed a dead baby badger with a pinapple in order to continue.
- Next ten minutes felt good, exploring, feeding the babies from animals and fruits.
- Ten minutes forward I was clueless again, walked for ten minutes, ran out of resources, and never found the eagle or whatever.
I would not recommend paying $10 for this.

reviewText:
Without spoiling the game, (I'll do that later) let's just say you are forced to do something you work really hard to prevent.  Then BAM!  That moment really sucked!   I don't really recommend the game just for that one forced event alone...

BUT, the biggest pain is having to constantly worry about getting food for your freakishly hungry cubs!!!  That is the whole game!  Digging up roots and bumping trees with your head to get apples to drop.  Once I got to kill a rat to feed one of my cubs.  Boring game!!!  Again, I don't recommend this game...  Maybe I should have played it longer, but that one forced event made me depressed!!!




(SPOILER ALERT!) Dev's... You should really have made the game so you could save all the cubs...  You should not have to leave one behind to die of starvation!  Lame move!  And what's up with having to constantly feed them!  Not realistic at all!  Bummer.  I was looking forward to this game being fun, not depressing and at times frustrating…

reviewText: Shelter is a beutifull game, but is it a game you want to play ? reviewText:
A survival game about a mother badger trying to keep her cubs alive while wandering through the forest. Many dangers lay ahead, including evil birds, wild rivers and starvation. Being a badger is not all sunshines and rainbows, I can tell you that.

The graphics in 'Shelter' are not bad and original but personally I thought they were a little on the bright side. The gameplay is mostly about running and hiding from other creatures and make sure your cubs make it aswell. You can give your cubs food you find but that's about it.

Sometimes when you've been running from danger you'll notice one (or more) of your cubs is missing. In my opinion this part could be a little more dramatic, which may be unrealistic but personally I did not really feel bad for getting them killed.

Overall Shelter is an OK and short game. It's not bad but to me it felt like it could be way more than it is now.

reviewText:
TRUE GEM

Let me start form the end. It was long time since I cried and even longer since I cried because of PC game well I think I can without shame say that Shelter made me reset this counter. I expect nice little game with badgers and it is that indeed. BUT  on top of that (perhaps like bonus) I get bucket of emotions and emotional knock out on the end.

Let's get to the game as it is. First that will hit you is graphic is unusual but very lovely in same time. You play as mother badger starting in your den with 5 little cubs and one of those need your help straight away as it is weak of starvation,
So you get it food or leave it behind your choice. Following is long journey for you and your litter as you take them from the den and on way to safety of mountains where they can learn what it mean to be badger. On your long and tiresome journey you will encounter many obstacles like dark and wolves, hunting eagle (or hawk i cant really tell), crossing creek during heavy rain and at last (not least) the forest fire.
But then your journey is finished and safety of mountain forest is front of you there is only last meadow to cross and last Eagle/hawk to avoid so you move on and......

What happen then I will not tell to avoid spoilers I only say this, after all the stress and fright of loosing my cubs what happened tear down the last wall and I sat there 5 minutes in tears. When someone make game that can pull you in so much that it slowly scrubbing away all those invisible walls you build so you can deal with everyday ♥♥♥♥ of world out there THAT game is definitely deserve space on your HD.

I am giving this 10/10 things that will make you feel like you are there and badgers this is game for you.

reviewText:
Experience the wild as a mother badger sheltering her cubs from harm. On their journey they get stalked by a bird of prey, encounter perils of the night, river rapids crossings, big forest fires and the looming threat of death by starvation.

Food is to be found, but is there enough for everyone? You will learn that the cubs need food not just to survive, but to enable them overcome the varying challenges they will face as they make their way through the world.

Are you ready for a truly different adventure, something that might evoke feelings you've never felt in a game before? In the wild, all living creatures are put to the test. The question in the end is who will survive to live another day?

Retro Family have once again composed a beautiful soundtrack to an original and graphically innovative setting in a world of nature where shelter is your only hope and survival your only goal.

reviewText: Shelter is a beautiful game; the art style is pared down while still being both pleasing and engaging. The music is similarly haunting, with sparse percussion accented by big open chords. You play as a mother badger, looking after your five cubs. You must find them food, guide them through fire and flood, protect them from predators that strike without warning.\n\nThe game is short -- about two hours -- but in that time it mangaged to evoke emotion without a single word of text or spoken dialog; it was a great example of show don't tell"
date: the best kind of interactive storytelling. The end
hoursPlayed: is quite poetic. And if the phrase "interactive storytelling" didn't just make you stop reading in disgust
voteText: Shelter is certainly worth your time."

Not my kind of game, the story and progession is a bit too slow for my taste. And if you wonder about the art style, well it is how a game would look if you didn't bother unwrapping the 3d objects and tile things correctly. Surprisingly well done style though. The game is good for those who like a slow game where you experience the life of a badger. I recommend the game as it is an interesting game, just not for me. :)

Turns out I'm a badger, which is a good start. I have baby badgers? That's fine. Look at this little scrub here, starving when there's a sammich a few feet away! Fed him and I'm off.
Little badgers are hungry. Apparently if you don't feed them equally then Michael Jackson's surgeons show up and start making them slowly turn white. You don't want a squad of honkees so make sure that little ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ Scruffybottom doesn't eat it all himself.

Fed each of them three or four things individually, then we ate a fox I fly-kicked. He was trying to sell my kids drugs so he was Asking For It™. You don't even know how badgers roll.

Anyway so a hawk that was apparently full of holes showed up and tried to snatch my mini-badgers, so I eluded it and ran back to the barrow. This clearly educational game taught me that there's no such thing as a day's meal when you have stripes because they all rolled in flour and died. 12/10.

Tl;dr badgers don't sleep, so don't ever go home. They need to eat their weight in food once every 10 minutes or they lose colour faster than a game boy screen in sunlight.
Very unique, casual and relaxing. :) I really enjoyed the artwork style and story.

My love for badgers and hatred of predatory birds has increased a great deal since buying this game.
Whilst I've not had much time to get back into playing Shelter (So I've not completed it, as of writing this) I do know that, up to the point I've gotten, this game is very, very nice.

The game's premise is simple: You're a female Badger, out in the back ♥♥♥♥ of nowhere, and you have to take your adorable little cubs to a better home somewhere else.
Your challenge is finding your way across obstacles, avoiding getting eaten by Eagles and other animals, and keeping your Cubs in check.

The art style is very simple, but that makes it better somehow- giving you more time to fall in love with your Badger and her cubs, and with the situation, rather than the surroundings. The audio is also nice, fitting with the whole experience.

If you value new experiences, and fantastic concepts, then you should definitely take a look at Shelter. It's not as expensive as that new Yanks Killing Russians 5" game

Shelter is admittedly a terribly short game with gameplay not too dissimilar from games like Lemmings and From Dust, with respect to ensuring the safety of your followers. However, the emotional journey the game takes you on, with you starring as a mother badger, is ultimately a unique and memorable experience. The game is a tribute to all mothers out there that would do anything to protect their young.

reviewText: Badger Simulator 2013.  Ever wanted to guide a family of mustielids through the wilderness?  WELL NOW'S YOUR CHANCE.  Seriously though it's ♥♥♥♥ing gorgeous and every time I lose a cub I die a little on the inside.  Can't wait for the sequel - LYNXES!
Short, sweet and, holy ♥♥♥♥, scandinavian as ♥♥♥♥.\n\nReally enjoyed this game, totally worth its price.
Stopped playing after mah baby got taken. ;_;\nLove the style & soundtrack.

It was very easy to find food, but the sense of loss and danger keep you on your toes.  The game pulls at you emotionally, but unfortunately fails to expound very much upon the mechanics it establishes.

For instance, none of my cubs ever became hungry enough to fall sick which could have added the challenge of leaving a cub behind and keeping the others safe while trying to find food. Although the game begins with a sick cub, this idea is not once revisited.

Overall, the game is wonderfully made and thoughtfully put together. I definitely recommend playing this, but I wish the ideas were a little more fleshed out.  I don't know if I can say that the $10 price isn't worth it, but the game's 1hr length definitely brings it under question.

Just finished this in an hour and I liked it.  What you get: A mostly mellow journey through what is basically a 3D painting, leading your five cubs through various dangers and foraging for food along the way. Why I liked it: The art style was refreshing and unique, and I had fun trying to keep my litter alive. The ending came abruptly but was fitting and makes me want to try again to see if I can save more than two of my cubs. Don't expect action or a deep sim-type experience from this. If you can appreciate a unique visual aesthetic, a nice soundtrack, and how everything blends to create an immersive world you may think ten dollars was worth it. I did.

reviewText: This game is inscrutable. I picked up a pineapple, dropped it, it rolled down a hill past an invisible wall, and I walked around trying to interact with things for a while. Eventually, I alt+F4'd out, started over, and walked about some woods for a bit before running out of fruit to give to my little badgers. And that was it.\n\nThere's probably more to Shelter than that, but the game makes no attempt to make it accessible to the player. There's no save-game function and movement is extremely slow, so I don't feel motivated to try again.

This game made me hate birds. It's charming as ♥♥♥♥, adept at punching you in the feels and gorgeous to look at/listen to, but now I hate all the birds.\n\nHard to justify the 10 AUD price tag, but pick it up on a sale and then rage at your horrible parenting skills.

Well... it's a Badger simulator! Quite a unique idea, and it's certainly interesting being put in the middle of the food chain, trying to protect your cute little badger cubs from those mean predators, then biting a mouse's head off and sneaking up and killing a fox then feeding it to them.\nOnly downside is that the game doesn't really have any replay value and isn't really that long.\nI suppose you can retry and see if you can get more of your cubs to the end the next time.

Shelter is a game with an interesting concept but deeply flawed implementation.  The game relies on you to build a bond with your progeny but never does anything to make you feel attached to them.  Because of this lack of attachment, the game breaks once you realize it’s easier to just let your children die and run to the next objective.  Combine this with twisting levels that are easy to get lost in and a playtime under two hours, it’s hard to recommend even when it’s on sale.

A short yet beautiful adventure where your maternal/paternal instincts take over.

It's a charming and short game about motherhood and trying to protect your young in a cold world.

The game clocks in a little over an hour yet it doesn't overstay its welcome with its simplistic mechanics of feeding your young, trying to keep them together and keeping them from being devoured. The game is pretty simple but keeping your young alive is surprisingly difficult and over the course of your hour you'll find plenty of twists and turns and new mechanics to keep things free.

You'll mostly be wandering around, trying to feed your children by either knocking down apples or even hunting small animals. There will even be times where you are met with more children than food and you have to choose who to feed (hungry children will fade and grow weaker and slower making them easy prey). Avoiding eagles, creatures of the night, trying to keep them calm when they run away scared and keeping them alive during natural disasters makes you grow attached to them.

My only criticism is that for a game so short there are loading screens (which are quick) but load into very different areas of the forest. Such a short game would have been much better at providing a more seamless transition between the areas" of the forest.

All in all it's a great game."
Suprisingly Good, experience the joys of nature in all her beauty, and cruelty.

reviewText: I enjoyed Shelter for what it was;  A casual survival game with a message about life to convey.  However, I cannot commend it for the story alone.  Clocking it at almost exactly 45 minutes, Shelter is remarkably short.  Despite the game being so short, it introduces a lot of gameplay variations, only to discard each one.  By the middle of the game, I had forgotten to butt trees for apples because there were so many ways to gather food.  Survival is hardly a struggle, just a happening in this game.  Fun mechanics, like the night level and river crossing, were discarded not 15 minutes after they were introduced.  The final level introduces nothing new, just the same easy Hawk-dodge mechanic from early in the game.  The game is also stuck between the do-it-yourself" school of gaming and the "please-hold-my-hand" brand of tutorial-based gameplay.  (The only challenge in the game is figuring out how to feed your baby in your den.  Everything else is given an instructional pop-up lesson.)  A fine message and an interesting artstyle
date: not worth the price of admission."

reviewText: Shelter is a short, simple, survival game where you play as a badger mother who must protect her five cubs from harm.  The roughly 1 hour long game consists of hunting and foraging for food, avoiding dangerous predators and traversing the perilous natural environment.  This game takes you on an emotional journey whereby maximum immersion comes from the attatchment the player feels for each of the badger cubs, and the devastation they feel from the loss of any one of them.\n\nWith a beautiful soundtrack, story and art style, this game is definately worth a play, especially if you can pick it up relatively cheaply.

The feels.

Shelter pulls you into the role of a mother badger who is trying to raise and protect five cubs through the forest. They squeal and follow you obediently as you rummage through the forest in search for food to keep up their health. They rush to the roots to get fed and you pick them up and choose which one to feed. It is a simple method, but as the days pass by in the forest, the terror rises.

A shadow of a large eagle swoops through the field, and you do your best to protect your cubs from the threat. You see that one of your cub's fur is turning dull- the lack of food is making it weaker. With agony you rush through the level in the hopes that the eagle doesn't swoop down to take one of your babies. It is terrifying, especially as you see the weak cub falling back.

And then it happens.

The majestic bird flies down and takes it away, but you can't stop. You have to keep going. There are still four more cubs that need protection.

This is one scenario that could happen to you depending on how well you play (I for example had to grieve over 4 dead cubs at the end). Early on the parental instincts will kick in as you try to keep them all alive. There is terror when one cub is missing, and the sense of failure as a parent for not being able to protect them.

It is a very good depiction of the wild life, and even though the game is short, the experience and emotions it brings out is worth more than other games I spent full prize on only to get disappointed with.

Shelter is an adventure survival game centered around playing as a mother badger, giving an overall pleasurable experience. Chances are that if you came to this page to view the game that means that you are okay with playing artistic indie games, and at a price of $10 I think this game is well worth the experience it supplies (and for those of you who are on a budget, this game can be picked up for around $2-3 during Steam sales whether it be Fall, Winter, or Summer).

As a survival adventure game, Shelter exceeds in its art style, which in my opinion can be best described as Low-Poly (if you play the game and grow to love the art style there is a couple of wonderful subreddits that showcase this kind of art style called /r/lowpoly, /r/low_poly, and /r/lowpoly2d).

Overall the experience is superb as you play as a mother badger who is sheltering her five cubs, with an overall arching story that is very compelling and what I would describe as short and sweet. I believe in moderation of story time, and Shelter can take roughly 60-90 minutes to complete. This may sound short to you, but there is an option for multiple play throughs as one may wish to complete the game with all five cubs (if they did not achieve that the first time) althought the ending will always be the same.
An additional mode was added at some point called Nurture" (under "extras" on the menu) which essentially allow you to play the game in a reminescent Tamagotchi like way. I mean this in  the sense that you are now allowed to explore the open world as a badger and *constantly revisit* your five cubs *every day* to *nurture* and feed them until they are adults. It's a relaxing game mode to me since it's a good way to unwind and passively listen to Shelter's amazing sound score.

Things that I did not like about the game mostly revolve around how the cubs that you are to protect have a janky AI which can be unresponsive in following you sometimes (it can range from not many occurences on a level to a fair amount) leading to the AI's impending death and you as the player completing the game without all five cubs. Another thing I noticed was that the environment may appear to be open world
date: but at least in the campaign mode you are very limited in what and where you can explore. Now in the "extra" feature mode of Nurture this is slightly alleviated but is still present. These two complaints of mine DO NOT DETRACT FROM THE OVERALL EXPERIENCE of the game
recommended: but are things that I reflected upon and complained about upon completion of the game.\n\nI would HIGHLY recommend this game
hoursPlayed: and it's coming sequel called Shelter 2 released by the same studio Might and Delight where in Shelter 2 you play as a lynx and have a supposedly more control and freedom over the open world. The trailer is absolutely magnificent and Shelter 2 will be released sometime next month. If it is anything like Shelte was then it will be a superb game with unique and touching plot points."

It's short and sweet. The game is about a badger that must protect her pups from the evils of nature while on a journey. Most of the interaction is limited to finding food for the pups and helping them avoid drowning, burning, foxes, and a bird. That damn bird. I really did feel bad the bird ate so many of the kiddies. They have such a horrible scream when they're getting plucked. The game only takes an hour to beat. I managed to only get one of the pups to the end. It might be worth playing again to get all of them to the end. I gotta say, the very final scene that plays after the credits ended gave me a big laugh. The asthetic of the game is really unique. It was a risky gamble, but it's beautifully weird and I dig it. The only thing I didn't like about it was it was too white. Everything looks more washed out than it should have been. More vibrant colors would have made the look even better. Perhaps, along with the twangy guitar soundtrack, the developers were going for giving the game the feel of a dream with the overly-white visuals. Regardless, Shelter is a quality experience. I do recommend it.

When I first found this game, i thought it was going to be a new and intriguing animal survival/simulator, a genre rarely touched or done well before. But it turned out that was only half the case. You only care for the badger kits, and you yourself do not need to eat at all (playing as the mother badger). The graphics are apealing and soundtrack is pleasant, but that means nothing to me if the gameplay isn't at its full potential, and im sure that a portion of the playerbase may feel the same. Plus it's very linear, not really having enough space to explore and have a grand adventure being lost in the woods. Don't get me wrong though, I did enjoy this game for the past hour and a half of playing it(which is the length of the game), foraging and occasionally hunting foxes, voles, and frogs to sate my babies' hunger. But i honestly think this game could have given a bit more in what it's focused on. Then again, I'm not entirely sure of the devolpers intentional feel they want the game to give to its players. If you want a charming, relaxing game that brings you closer to your [badger] family, then this may be one of those games. However, if you desire a more challenging game that truly tests your will to survive (this may be the case in the game's sequel: Shelter 2")

Shelter is a beautiful game depicting the life of a mother badger. I love the art style, but the text is often unreadable (fortunately only menu text is important). It only has partial controller support (you need a mouse to use the menus and the control tips are for keyboard and mouse). It's a short and interesting story told entirely through actions.

Technically it's entirely an escort mission with stealth elements, but Might & Delight manage to use the escort format to connect you to your pups and make you regret their demise.

reviewText: If you liked the unique aesthetics and interactive-soundscapey-ness of Proteus, Shelter might be the game for you. It also sports a clearer objective - you're a mother badger, you've got five baby badgers to feed and take care of, and the rest of the world is against you (or at least, the rest of the world that's bigger than you are). Along the way you'll be contending with hungry birds, sneaky foxes, surging rapids and raging fires, all whilst you try to keep your quintet of kids in check. It's a short experience - little more than an hour - but a memorable one, and the soundtrack is utterly superb. Stay past the end credits for a scene that ties a nice, thoughtful bow around the whole package.

It's original, and the environment has a nice feeling to it, but overall it's slow and boring. Also not being able to save the game whenever you like is annoying, as it forces you to complete a level before exiting.

A story of a mother Badger, and her 5 cubs.  You roam the woods in search of food, adventure, and to find what it truly means to be a Badger.  There will be panic, hardships, fun, predators, and quite possibly one of the most innovative forms of story telling I have ever played in a game.

This is a great game for someone looking for an artsy, emotional sort of experience. Playing as a mother badger was a stressful and enriching experience from a storyline perspective. I will say that the game is short, but the ending tends to stick with you.

Controls can be a bit funny when having to feed the badger pups. You aren't always going to be able to feed the one you want, especially in the night-time portions of the game. Other than that, they follow you around quite nicely and don't get into too much trouble!

I would certainly recommend this game to friends.

This game is a cool concept, but remember it's just that - a concept. The music can be distractingly frenetic (I'm not sure if they're trying to procedurally generate it or it's just French), it's quite short, and ultimately it doesn't feel fully fleshed out.

Which isn't to say there's nothing to like. It takes almost no time to feel genuinely protective of your cubs, and chaperoning them through the world is fun. And it has a satisfying ending, even if it is short.

Finally, if you beat it, make sure to let the credits roll completely. You'll feel better.

Shelter is a quite short but beautiful designed game with an unique art style way off the mainstream. You and your cubs have to survive in the unforgiving wilderness with new obstacles to master each day. It creates an intense emotional connection with your offspring, when you try to find food and hide from the enemy to survive the day.
I've started to give names to little ones to help me remember wich one to feed :)

Evocative in scope with gorgeous art and music, but perhaps a bit too 'on rails' for its own good, something the sequel supposedly addresses. Still, Shelter stands strong as a fairly unique experience, only vaguely comparable to the likes of Flower and Journey; consider it endorsed.
Proud possom mother loves her young\nGo play please, help children live, remember to give them plenty of yums to be strong.

I didn't realise you could actually keep all of the babies alive, when one died I was like 'oh god! Oh well guess I can't change it' And I got to the end of the game alone, and was like 'that was sad'\nLooked online... now I feel like an awful hedgehog mother
♥♥♥♥ the river level, 7.4/10 too much water.

Overal, loved it. It is beautiful, casual and appropriately entertaining for its subject matter. I do have an issue with the beginning since directions could be better and I notice the colors tend to have a bleached quality  about it (maybe that's just the style, I don't know). It may be good for children since it is simple to play and very pleasant. If you like animals and open worlds, I recommend this game.
very boring

Shelter is... probably not even a fraction of what it means to be a mother, but still, the fear was almost unbearable.
Run a bit, look behind you, count the cubs following you, repeat.
Try to give the turnips and carrots to the hungriest ones as they scurry around you.
At night, the howls, your cubs panicking and running off, and then that terrible, terrible squeek...

I finished the first run with only one cub left. I will try again, but not that soon. It requires some mental stamina.

In the ending scene, the game broke its apparently only principle. But that was fine, as I stopped caring about _that_ long before.

If you are looking for great graphics or tons of action look somewhere else. If you want gameplay that is is fresh and unlike anything you have ever played before get this now. There isn't a single line of dialogue or even a human being, but few games have ever made me feel as attached to the characters" as this one did. If you don't give this game a try you are doing yourself and your imagination a disservice. This is the type of game that will make you rethink what gaming really is and what it could be."

This is a cute little game. Super short (I finished it in 45 minutes (that includes watching the credits).\n\nI can't say it's worth any more than $1, though, since it's so short (I paid less than $1)
Great game, the only time I can be a Mummy!
Shocking experience!

An hour-long, linear, escort mission with no replay value, Shelter would hugely benefit from a more open, perhaps randomly generated environment. As it is, the game funnels you through a very specific experience with no deviations and very little opportunity to improvise or interact with the environment. It's maybe worth playing through once, but by the end of it you may be wondering what all the fuss was about and wishing there was a lot more meat on the bone.

In this game/story with no words you are the mother of five babies which you must feed, guide and protect until they grow up. Haveing all five baby make you the surper mom but it becomes more diffucult to care for all of them.\nI would expect to find this game in a museum for its art direction and way of story telling story.\nHint for the first level give the vegtable to the grey baby.

Shelter is a fast paced FPS with excellent controls and beautifully designed enemies. You join Captain Alexander Spence in his epic quest to save the planet and help him battle his way across the Americas. The game is a little short and lacks narrative, but all in all, if you like super violence mixed with intense knee biting strategy, Then this is the game for you!

Very cute game that plays strongly with the player's emotions. The objective of the game is to play the role of a badger mother tending to her cubs. You feed the cubs while progressing through the world and the various 'stages' and protecting them from hazard. Losing a cub leaves a feeling of loss and a failure as a badger mother.

It's very tempting to speed through the game. This is a game that's meant to be enjoyed in moderation, for the sights and the overall feeling of attachment to the cubs. The scenery is beautiful, but a bit too bright/washed out. It gives it a consistent, calming, pastel colored, albeit polygonal world. If you do try the game, do try to stop and enjoy the surroundings. Highlights of the game include stage 2 (starry night/mother's light), feeling of loss upon losing a badger cub, and a well executed ending.

It's a very short game, and a bit debatable as to whether 10$ is really the correct price point for it. The nurture mode is apparently modelled after a Tamagotchi style game and looks promising: if returning to the game daily to feed your cubs apples that you knock off from trees with your head and radishes you pluck from the ground is your thing.

This isn't a Modern Warfare game. It's not meant to be graphically intensive, it doesn't have guns, and it's not overly realistic in the department of European Badger diets. It's not meant to be Badger Simulator 2013, though some would be eager to call it that. If the description above doesn't appeal to you, then don't bother.

It's a casual, experimental game that's meant to be cute. You want to try this game if you're looking for something unique and are inclined to cute, casual games and prone to the emotional aspect.

I love this game, but in all honesty, I might be biased... just a bit.
Yeah pretty ♥♥♥♥♥♥, I wouldn't recommend anyone buy it!

Pros: Cute design. Emotional trauma. Headbutting trees. Ripping cute foxes apart with your mighty badger teeth.
Cons: Way too short for a $10 game. It only took me 2 hours to finish because I got confused at the start and at the end (Should I give my only food item to the clearly dead cub? Should I sprint across a wide open field, trusting in my majestic badger legs to outrun a bird?).

Don't miss out on the absolute best badger game out there! If it's on sale.
