Very nice little game. Thought it would be quite boring at first but the fact that you need to protect 5 little badger babies is more intense than it seems. Amazing visual style tat I haven't seen before and very well fitting soundtracks.\nDefinitely a game with a lot more than meets the eye.
If you've ever wondered to yourself how a mother badger feels BOY DO I HAVE THE GAME FOR YOU

Even though I feel like this game missed out on realizing its full thematic potential, I still found it more emotionally stirring and visually mesmerizing than many much bigger titles out there.

Shelter toys with players' familiarity with game conventions and our notions of a control-success correlation by allowing randomness to factor into the cubs' survival. Although I think the developers did this to emphasize themes of survival-of-the-fittest and the inevitable losses of parenthood, it doesn't make for the most enjoyable gameplay experience.

At just over an hour, Shelter is just the right length as it compresses and contextualizes these themes admirably, yet still fails to provide a compelling progression of gameplay mechanics. While I would have liked to have seen the game more fully fleshed-out, I still laud Might and Delight for tackling such unconventional subject matter within the medium.

A simple linear badger simulator, you take on the role of mother guiding her children through many scenarios.  I recommend it, however the ten dollar price tag is a little steep.  Maybe it's just me and my lack of money all the time.  Anyway, there are different challenges such as guiding your cete through a forest fire or running past rapids.  Then there is the always haunting threat of starvation.
badger simulator 2013\n\nit's quite fun.

This game is different, stressful and relaxing at the same time! It makes me wish for more games where you take on the role of an animal and do animal survival things. The low-poly and stylish texturing of the world is something I find very appealing, the art direction of this game is certainly one of its strengths. I've still got plenty of the game left however; I had to stop playing for a bit because I go so upset losing one of my badger cubs!

This is one of the most depressing and simple games I have ever played. I ended up losing two babies on the final level and only keeping three alive. This game may not be a good game content-wise, or gameplay-wise, or even scenery-wise, but it sure as hell got me emotional and had a deep meaning. This is a game for those animal lovers and children lovers out there.

This is basically The Last of Us, only with badgers. It has almost the same emotional punch, in about 1/10th the time.

Shelter is actually a brief, fairly linear story that does exactly what it needs to and no more. If you're expecting a full survival game or something of the like, you'll be disappointed. Shelter is a brief, simple experience that nonetheless affected me very much.

If that sounds appealing, pick it up. If you're on the fence, wait until a sale and don't go in expecting anything other than to care for some badger cubs and their mom.
Wow. What a great little game.\nGorgeous art style, great sense of emotional investment, really well delivered.
Definitely not worth paying full price for, but if you can get it on sale, it's fun to spend a bit of time in it.  The art style is beautiful.

Hmm...what can I say. I don't really care about the length, as I knew it was going to be short. That said...I do like 'interactive stories' such as Dear Esther. However...I found this game waaaaaaaaay too pretentious and did not enjoy it very much.\n\nGraphic style is quite special, and the ending after the credits is kind of cool, but I still wouldn't recommend it.

Amazing art, with simple, captivating gameplay. You'll need stealth to survive eagle attacks, agility to capture prey, and a sharp mind to keep your pups fed. A unique experience you won't find anywhere else.

Shelter is a survival game where you control a mother badger whose task is to take care of her cubs, feed them, and lead them to safety while protecting them from predators and other various threats. It's a short (~90 minutes) and linear game but very beautifully crafted and does a fine job of eliciting fear, sadness and joy as you make your journey. It's easy to get caught up in the experience and feel as though you're actually taking care of these cubs. That moment when a hawk swoops down and lifts away your child, or watching the rushing water carry them downstream, is surprisingly gut-wrenching. You feel as though you failed not just as someone playing a videogame but also as a parent to these virtual creatures.

The game's visual style will probably be hit or miss with players. The blocky, pastel-colored design is unique and interesting, but the high brightness/gamma while playing can feel kinda strange. When I was done it took me a few minutes to re-adjust my eyes back to normal. The game also makes great use of audio cues and sound effects throughout to help make you feel more immersed in the nature setting. The camera work can be shoddy at times when near trees, rocks, walls, etc., but I didn't find it to be distracting enough to be a major concern.

Overall, Shelter is a game that does a beautiful job of telling a story about the trials of parenting and the circle of life. A short yet emotionally powerful experience.
Sweet little game in which you find yourself looking after your little cubs. Slow pace but sometimes it's good to put the racers and shooters aside and chill out. Suprisingly good. Worth a try!

Sadly due to the clunkiness and bugs I can't recommend this lovely idea for a game, I made three attempts and each time a bird snatched one of my babies from within the confines of a bush where they are supposed to be safe, the bugginess and pathfinding are major drawbacks.
Good game

I went into this game with no prior knowledge of how this game's style was presented. I fell in love with the art style the second I walked out of the badger den. I loved the immersion that this game brought upon me when playing. It felt like I was in the forest, walking and foraging, caring for young badger-lings. Another point that makes this game wonderful is the music. The music within really adds to the fact that you are a badger caring for your young. When things get heated, so does the music making for a game with suspense around every tree. I'd put this as one of my all-time favourite game just because of the sheer immersive effects of the art, music and gameplay. Go buy it now! 10/10

Have you ever dreamed that you were a badger? No? Maybe just a mother, and look after your children? Neither? Well, fine. But if trying to survive in a harsh environment while emotionally bonding with your offspring and protecting them from danger sounds appealing to you, this might be an experience that is worth your time.
Excellent! :)
A lovely game with fantastic art but rather subpar gameplay. But whatever, you get to be a badger mom!

This is not what you would consider a normal game. This is the definition of indie, although I'd hesitate to even call it a game. More of an interactive experience than anything else. There is no score kept, minimal tutorial, and very little in the term of gameplay. The goal of Shelter is to guide 5 badger cubs to safety through various different environments as the parent badger, making sure all five are kept safe from predators and well fed. The game" takes about an hour to complete
date: but that hour is one emotional rollercoaster. If you have a couple bucks and a little patience Shelter is well worth it. Shelter does a phenomenal job of connecting the player to the badger family he/she is responsible for
recommended: especially considering the short completion time.  With the right mind set going into this game it is excellent. I definitely recommend this game to anyone looking for something to chew on after they've finished."

reviewText: I enjoyed Shelter for what it was;  A casual survival game with a message about life to convey.  However, I cannot commend it for the story alone.  Clocking it at almost exactly 45 minutes, Shelter is remarkably short.  Despite the game being so short, it introduces a lot of gameplay variations, only to discard each one.  By the middle of the game, I had forgotten to butt trees for apples because there were so many ways to gather food.  Survival is hardly a struggle, just a happening in this game.  Fun mechanics, like the night level and river crossing, were discarded not 15 minutes after they were introduced.  The final level introduces nothing new, just the same easy Hawk-dodge mechanic from early in the game.  The game is also stuck between the do-it-yourself" school of gaming and the "please-hold-my-hand" brand of tutorial-based gameplay.  (The only challenge in the game is figuring out how to feed your baby in your den.  Everything else is given an instructional pop-up lesson.)  A fine message and an interesting artstyle
date: not worth the price of admission."

reviewText: Shelter is a short, simple, survival game where you play as a badger mother who must protect her five cubs from harm.  The roughly 1 hour long game consists of hunting and foraging for food, avoiding dangerous predators and traversing the perilous natural environment.  This game takes you on an emotional journey whereby maximum immersion comes from the attatchment the player feels for each of the badger cubs, and the devastation they feel from the loss of any one of them.\n\nWith a beautiful soundtrack, story and art style, this game is definately worth a play, especially if you can pick it up relatively cheaply.

In the 2nd lvl, where i couldn't run... The only reason i finished it at all is because i left one of my cubs to starve, and then started running. yay. waste of time.
Also, you can't save, so you cannot quit mid-level without having to replay it all over. They're not that long, but still...
And invisible walls. kthxbai.

Shelter was a game I had been reading about for a while and kind of forgot about. However, upon rediscovering it, buying it and playing it, I found that it offers a very unique experience not found anywhere else! You play as a mother badger trying to escort her young along the paths of growing up and maturing to the point of taking care of themselves. You will escort them away from hungry flying owls, wolves in the night, forest fires and even huge waves of water trying to sweep them away! I found myself caring too much for those little guys. And you'll also find that the ending is completely bitter sweet. Definitely worth your time.

Shelter is a hauntingly beautiful experience. Faced with decisions that will horrify you the game pits you in the middle of a vicious reality that will make you awe over the beauty and cry over the heartbreak, sometimes simultaneously.

As another reviewer said, welcome to BADGER SIMULATOR 2013!
I recommend ignoring the hype and deciding what you are looking for in a game before trying.
Your enjoyment of Shelter will be largely influenced by what you look for in a game. If you go into Shelter looking for a fin traditional game then you may be disappointed. What Shelter offers in this department is non-traditional graphics, invisible walls, long corridors with little explorations, lite-survival and caretaking elements, some somewhat neat stealth take downs, and annoying birds of death. Oh, and bugs that will cause your badger children to die.
However, if you are looking for a game that also offeres a unique and harrowing experience that puts you in the shoes of motherhood in the animal wilds, trying to do whatever it takes as an omnivore in the middle of the food chain.
The graphics remind me of picture books from childhood, recalling tales and fables about animals and their children in their world, full of morals and whatnot. This may be bunk to others, but as an artist it drew me into the world and realitic//naturalistc grapics would have had a lesser effect on me.
The soundtrack itself is wonderful, blending into the game perfectly. I cannot say much about it specificly other than it filled the world just right, layering and never pulling me away.
The sound effects are good as they should be, the badgers yip and yap in communication, the predatory birds caws are terrifying when first heard, and other animals sounds serve as environmental clues. This is all as it should be.
So the real meat of this gaming experience comes to down to the scripted experiences you progress through. Your badger children age and grow as you take them through several environments, each containing various hazards such as darkness, fire, and flooding. You must constantly provide them food of either the vegetable of flesh variety.
If you are not the type of person looking to be placed in the role of protector, mother, leader, provider; if you don't find yourself becoming emotionally attached as you play games, then you may want to give Shelter a pass.
I am a white male gamer, age 32 and fall somewhere in the middle of attachment/unattachment. When my first two badger died to something in the darkness I was sad, but I expected it sooner or later. They were weak and scared. When my next child died in a flood it was upsetting but I still had two strong children to look out for. When one of them was taken by a large raptor because I took a wrong turn in some underground tunnels and came out the dangerous end, I was screaming at the top of my lungs at the computer screen.
This game go to me.

This little game packs a huge emotional punch. The aim is to keep your brood of cute little baby badgers alive - you get attached to them very quickly, so be prepared to feel like the worst person in the world if one dies. They're wayward little scamps who don't always go where you want them to, which keeps things interesting. The world is also very pretty to look at, which always helps.

People you cohabit with will also get some amusement from your gameplay - mainly due to your irrational cries of 'GET AWAY FROM MY BABY' peppered with the odd 'JUST EAT THE STUPID TURNIP - NO, NOT YOU, I MEANT STRIPY - GAAAAAAH'

Shelter is an interesting and meditative experience.

The art direction is superb, though the choice of the overly bright color ramp is a bit disappointing, as I feel the graphics would be so much better if the colors were more rich. However, I believe the intent is to mimic the feel of cut construction paper, which follows the general art direction.

Sound and music are superb. The environment feels alive and popualted at all times. The musical cues are used to great effect to emphsize mood and provide backdrop, though they're honestly not needed and turning the music off does not make the game feel empty at all. That is incredibly rare.

The core gameplay concept is very simple: Shephard and feed your younglings. However, Nature is cruel and uncaring. The game is pretty brutal, and each time I lost one of my young I actually protested aloud. You will build a connection if you allow yourself the immersion.

Brilliant little game, highly recommended.

this game puts you into a mindset of parenthood aand survival. You don't realize it at first but you begin to develope an actual connection with the (cubs?). Short, sweet, and held my attention the entire game. Its worth a play.

Great game!
I enjoyed every minute. It's such a nice change to play a game that feels this original.
I very much look forward to replaying it and any future releases from Might & Delight.
10/10

After playing for several traumatic hours back when this Shelter, I finally came back and finished it today. This was probably my favorite game of the year. I nearly cried through the whole thing. Despite starting right at the end the last scene still impacted me so much.\n\nPlay this game.

Definitely an interesting experience. You definitely feel like the mother trying to keep track of her kids who run around and pause all the time. I found myself counting heads every few minutes. Some of the lack of control in some areas was a bit frustrating, but I enjoy myself.

Shelter is a quite short but beautiful designed game with an unique art style way off the mainstream. You and your cubs have to survive in the unforgiving wilderness with new obstacles to master each day. It creates an intense emotional connection with your offspring, when you try to find food and hide from the enemy to survive the day.
One of the most strange and attractive survivor game that I've played! Especially when I love badgers

Pretty cool and sad, very sad game.  You play as a mother badger leading her badger babies across the dangers of the forest to safety.  Some quick things: Completion will take somewhere between an hour to two hours.  Simple controls, decent polygonal graphics, music is very moody, but in a good way, simple story, and a think about life kind of ending. Overall, pretty good, but I wouldn't pay more than a few dollars because the game is really short with minal replayability. Comes with another game called nurture which requires you to login every day to feed your babies - they could have left that one out.

Like many others I had the food stuck in my mouth bug. I was screaming at the computer, yelling at my mummy badger to drop the food to feed the baby badger. She didn't, I lost him.

I had the intense lag during the night stage. It was somewhat manageable, but during certain sections I really felt it. (When you play, you'll understand which sections I mean)

Yet, even with the bugs, it was an amazing game. I did not connect with my babies alot, but it was gut-wrenching to see them die to my mistake, and they are ADORABLE.

Helps that I picked it up cheap.. not sure its worth the $9.99 price tag otherwise, though I have yet to try Nurture mode. So do take this with a pinch of salt.

All in all, good game =)

Brought to you by Might and Delight with beautiful graphics, at least I like the textures a lot. Hunt, collect food or get eaten. Developers said they want the human factor removed from this game, and they success. You experience everything from predators to forest fire.

But whatever you do, the nature cycle is inevitable.

If you are in search of an authentic badger simulation experience, then look no further as 'Shelter' is the pinnacle of badger simulation history.

A fun simple game.

I know it is trying to evoke emotion. You have to protect your little badgers. But I would be walking, and suddenly notice I was missing a baby badger. Just gone. Oh, ok. There was nothing very tragic about it.

The aesthetic is nice, and the levels are nicely differentiated. None of it is too difficult. Definitely worth a play through.

A game with a simple objective - survive - is backed with chords, arpeggios and rattling snare drums and cymbals that conveys threat, comfort and achievement. A worthwile game to pay for and play. So play it.

Fun to play in it's own right. Comparing it to too many other games will not favour this one although as the actual game is fairly short (around 2 hours). Depending on what kind of person you are, however, those 2 hours can be a rather gripping experience. Protecting helpless badger babies from predators, storms or wildfire for a few hours is very fun and very engrossing.\n\nIf you're the kind of person who likes Watership Down or Don Bluth films, get this game. They've also added a semi-sandbox mode which takes some inspiration from the tamagootchi toys of the 90s.

So, I just spent the past hour and a half or so of my life being a mother badger.
Let that one sink in for a bit.
It was... strange, and fun, and don't even get me started on the elegance and beauty of the design, the beautiful soundtrack, and the minimalism of commands in today's gaming world where most games lead you by the hand start to finish....
I started off with five little badger pups, and brought one into full adulthood. I am proud.
Go, get the game, be the badger mother and support this wonderful studio. We need more beautiful and artistic games like this!
If there's one thing about Shelter, with its aluring, beautiful graphics, it is that it is imposible to see anything! Also, the noise when your cub gets eaten in the dark.

reviewText: Shelter is a mother badger simulator.  It does a wonderful job making you really care about taking care of your cubs.  I lost two of my five throughout the journey and have never felt such a tangible sense of failure in a video game before.  Even surpassing how terrible I feel when I let pikmin drown.  This is a really great experience worth playing through.  The ending is strangely affecting.  This game is really short though. At just barely over an hour you may want to wait for a sale before picking this up.

This game was a beautiful and interesting ride. Playing the role of a mother Badger, you have to travel through locations and events while feeding and caring for your Badger babies.  The sounds and score are enjoyable, and the game is a simple, yet challenging adventure. The colors and menu font/color tend to be a little disorienting at first, but you'll adjust, and it'll be worth it in the end.\n\nI reccomend this game if you're looking for a short, yet enjoyable game.

This is a spoilerfree review of an entire playthrough of the game.\nIn Shelter you play as a mother-badger trying to protect her baby badgers while guiding them through one danger after another. Like really, staying in the beginning cave would have been a better idea but whatever. The question you have to ask yourself is this: Is that enough for you to care? The game doesnt give you more than these are your children you are the mother protect them" as a reason to care. The artstyle is interesting I wouldn't say good nor bad. The problem with it is that your baby badgers really dont look cute. They squeak in a kind of cute way and that is as good as it gets. This leads to my first problem: I didnt give a ♥♥♥♥ about my baby badgers. Of course I fed them since really there is nothing else to do in this game other than feeding walking and hiding. THe badgers stupidity doesnt help either. Lost 2 badgers to their own stupidity and another one was just suddenly gone without an explanation. That left me with 2 that I still didnt care all to much about. Those 2 made it to the end at least. The gameplay itself is a stealth escort mission that manages to be more annoying than most because of food problems and badger stupidity.  The music did its job

reviewText:
Definitely an “artsy” game. If you aren’t the type of person who sees games as another form of artistic expression, don’t bother with this. The graphics are a stylized, washed-out look and the gameplay is minimalistic, to put it generously. It seems extremely insubstantial for MSRP, and if I had paid that I’d feel cheated. However, 50% or more off and I’d be happy with the purchase.

Just a note: developer, why did you pick the most evil animal on Earth for us to be sympathetic for? Maybe that was the cunning plan: to show those terrifying creatures from Farcry 4 to just be trying to survive…by biting people’s legs off.
nice

loved it! i completed the game slowly but sureley and its awesome! almost all my pups died! great storeyline. i just hate that ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ eagle! amazing ending (kinda sad) but good. i love the idea of this game and the creaters! im a huge fan of games like these and its well worth your money. i loved it, theirs also a extra wich is cool. oh and by the way try not to let your cubs die from the fox. i almost cried. the ONLY problem with this game is that i got so attached to my cubs and over protected. and as each cub died i almost cried D: but other than that great game 9/10 for the great work!

My babies and I survived everything all the way until our log collapsed into the darkness.. and I realized I only had four. I panicked for about five minutes but knew I had to quickly find a safer spot for the remaining babies. Then I guess I ran too fast, and I lost one to the dark. Then, two starved to death in the dark and wouldn't eat. So I had to leave them behind. I had one baby with me finally and I was fierce and protective, but that baby was swept away by a wave while crossing the river. In the end, I didn't even care if I lived or died, and I was eaten by a huge bird.\n\nMy heart is broken. So broken. :(

This game was a great and emotional rollercoaster...


Until the end. I'm giving it a thumbs up but the ending just makes me want to give it a thumbs down.

Prepare your tissues.

A short, unique game that leaves a lasting imprint on you with its simple commands, eerie soundtrack, art and storyline. It really makes you think and leaves you feeling like you experienced a life and journey with these little badgers.

This is a game in which your experience will vary depending on how immersed you are in it and how much you care about the cubs you are tasked with protecting. It's very short and there's not really that much to it, but the ending is executed perfectly and the art style is nice. Since it's not that expensive, I would recommend it.

This game is incredibly good. The art, music, even the story. It doesn't explain the game through words or images, instead it shows the storyline through emotion. Everything about this game is amazing. It is definatley worth the buy if you want a beautiful game that is destined to tug at your strings. I would truly like to thank the makers of this game for bringing it upon us, Thank you. It truly shows the nature of how far a mother is willing to go to protect her children.
